question: Iceberg phenomenon is depicted by all of the following diseases except:
exp: Iceberg phenomenon is not shown by diseases which have no carrier state such as: - Rabies - Tetanus - Measles - Rubella - Peussis Tip of iceberg Submerged pa of iceberg Composition Clinical cases Latent, inapparent, pre symptomatic, Undiagnosed cases and carriers Visibility to clinician Visible Invisible Prime impoance for Clinician Epidemiologist Detection Diagnostic tests Screening tests Useful level of prevention Secondary Secondary

question: Which of the following characteristics is not of much impoance in a screening test-
exp: ref: ref: Park&; s 23rd edition pg 137 Screening test must satisfy the criteria of acceptability, repeatablity and validity, desides others like yield, simplicity, safety, rapidity, ease of administration and cost. Specificity: defined as the ability of a test to correctly identify those who do not have the diesase, that is "true negatives". A screening test need not have high specificity.

question: Time difference between screening test and standard test is known as-
exp: Screening is the search for unrecognised disease or defect by means of rapidly applied tests, examinations or other procedures in apparently healthy individuals. Lead time is the advantage gained by screening. it is the time period between diagonosis by early detection and diagonosis by other means. That is lead time is the time difference between diagonosis by screening tests and standard test. Parks textbook of preventive and social medicine. K Park. Edition 23. Pg no: 136

question: Validity of a test is based upon all except
exp: Ref: Parks 23rd edition pg 138 Validity (accuracy): refers to what extend the test accurately measures which it purpos to measure. has two components: sensitivity and specificity. note: Precision / repeatability / reliability: that is test must give consistent redults when repeated more than once on the same individual or material, under same conditions.

question: Example of Multiphase screening is:
exp: Multiphasic screening: application of two or more screening tests in combination to a large number of people at one time. Example: annual health check ups. Multipurpose screening: screening by more than one test done simultaneously to detect more than one disease. Example: screening of a pregnant women for VDRL, HIV, HBV serological tests on a blood sample. Mass screening: Screening test applied on large population. Eg- CXR in elderly. High risk/ selective screening: Applied on high risk groups. Eg- screening for HIV in commercial sex workers.
opa: Chest X-ray for TB large population

question: If biochemical test gives the same reading of early sample on reputed testing, it is inferred that the measurement is-
exp: . biochemical test gives the same reading of early sample on reputed testing, it is inferred that the measurement is-precise. ref: park&; s textbook, 22 nd edition, pg no 22

question: High false positive cases in a community signify that disease has-
exp:
the term "false positive "means that patients who do not have the disease are told that they have the disease. in this case, normal healthy people may be subjected to fuher diagnostic tests, at some inconvenience, discomfo, anxiety and expense untill their freedom from disease is established. a screening test with a high specificity will have few false positives. false positives not only burden the diagnostic facilities, but they also bring discredit to screening programmes. high false postives of a disease in a community signifies high incidence and low prevalence.

ref; park&; s textbook of preventive and social medicine, 22 nd edition, pg no132

question: Diagnostic power of the test is reflected by-
exp: Ref: Parks 25th edition pg 153 Predictive value reflects the diagnostic power of a test. Positive predictive value indicates the probability that a patient with a positive test result has, in fact, the disease in question. The more prevalent disease in a given population, the more accurate will be the predictive value of a positive screening test. As prevalence decrease, positive predictive value decreases.

question: All comprise inherent propeies of a screening test except-
exp: Ref: Parks 23rd edition pg 140 Yield is not an inherent propey of screening test. Yield is the amount of previously unrecognized disease that is diagnosed as a result of screening effo. It depends on many factors: Sensitivity and specificity of the test Prevalence of disease Paicipation of individuals in the detection programme.

question: Specificity measures -
exp: specificity is defined as the ability of a test to identify correctly those who do not have the disease, that is true negatives. ref; parks gextbook, ed22, pg no 131

question: All are true about "lead time" except
exp: Concept of Lead Time Lead time - Lead time is the period between early detection by Screening and diagnosis by other means later in life Lead time is the "Advantage gained by screening" Detection programs should be restricted to those conditions in which there is considerable time lag The benefits of the programme must be seen in term of its outcomes
opa: Lead time is the period between early detection by Screening and diagnosis by other means later in life
opb: Lead time is the advantage gained by screening
opc: Detection programs should be restricted to those condition in which there is considerable time lag

question: A population of 1000 people in whom the prevalence of disease XYZ is 50%. ABC screening test was used to screen disease which has specificity and sensitivity of 50 %. What is positive predictive value of screening test ABC.
exp: Total Population = 1000 Prevalence = 50% People have Disease = 500 Not have Disease = 500 Method 1 Test Disease [?] Th [?] A TP? B FP? Th C FN? D TN? 500 (given) 500 (given) 1000 (given) Test Disease [?] Th [?] A 250 B 250 Th C 250 D 250 Method 2 ( Baye's Theorum)

question: High sensitive
exp: Ref: Parks 23rd edition pg 139. Sensitivity = (True positive) / (True positive + false negative) High sensitivity means high true positive. So, false negative results will be low.

question: In the Iceberg phenomenon of diseases, Tip of Iceberg shows
exp: Ice Berg Phenomenon Tip- Cases - Responsibility of Clinician - Uses diagnosis - 2deg prevention Hidden/Submerged Poion- Carriers/Subclinical/Preclinical and latent cases - Responsibility of Epidemiologist - Uses screening - 2deg prevention

question: The screening strategy for prevention of blindness from diabetic retinopathy according to the NPCB involves-
exp: Ref: Parks 23rd edition pg 137 Screening will be most productive if applied selectively to high-risk groups, the groups defined on the basis of epidemiological research.

question: If prevalence of a disease increases, what is true-
exp: Ref: Parks 25th edition pg 153. Positive predictive value depends on prevalence: Note: PPV increases as prevalence increases. PPV decreases as prevalence decreases. But sensitivity and specificity is independent of prevalence.

question: Mammography has 90% sensitivity and 98% specificity for breast carcinova. What is the probability that woman with breast carcinoma remains un diagnosed for 2 consecutive years?
exp: False positive = 1- sensitivity = 1- 0. 9 = 0. 1 For 2 consecutive years = 2x0. 1=0. 2

question: Most number of false positives by a screening test is becuase of?
exp: Ref: Parks 23rd edition pg 140. PPV decreases as prevalence decreases. As PPV decreases it means that TP is decreasing. This is accompanied by an increase in FP PPV =TP /(TP +FP)

question: The usefulness of a screening test in a community depends on its-
exp: Ref: Parks 23rd edition pg 139 An ideal screening test should have 100% sensitivity. Sensitivity is defined as the ability of a test to identify correctly all those who have the disease, that is "true positive"

question: Diagnostic power of a test is reflected by
exp: Diagnostic power of Screening test: Predictive accuracy (it tells the actual no. of people having the disease or not having the disease out of those shown positive or negative by a screening test, respectively) Diagnostic power of a screening test to correctly identify a disease: Positive predictive value(PPV). Diagnostic power of a screening test to correctly exclude a disease: Negative predictive value (NPV) Ref: Parl 25th edition Pgno: 153

question: True positive is indicated by-
exp: Ref: Parks 23rd edition pg 139 Sensitivity = TP / (TP + FN) Sensitivity is defined as the ability of a test to identify correctly all those who have the disease, that is "true positive".

exp: Ref: Parks 23rd edition pg 136 specificity is defined as the ability of a test to identify those who do not have the disease. That is true negatives.

question: If rapidly progressive cancers are missed by a screening test, which type of bias will occur?
exp: Length time bias is a form of selection bias Fast-growing tumours generally have a shoer asymptomatic phase than slower-growing tumours. Thus, there is a shoer period of time during which the cancer is present in the body. As a result, if the same number of slow-growing and fast-growing tumours appear in a year, the screening test detects more slow-growers than fast-growers. If the slow-growing tumours are less likely to be fatal than the fast growers, the people whose cancer is detected by screening do better Ref: Park 23rd edition Pgno: 74

question: Which one of the following will be affected by inter- observer variation in epidemiological studies
exp: the term sensitivity was introduced by Yerushalmy in 1940 s as a statistical index of diagnostic accuracy. it has been defined as the ability of a test to identify correctly all those who have the disease that is true positive. it also gets affected by the intern observer variations in the epidemiological studies. ref: park&; s textbook of preventive and social medicine, 22 nd edition, pg no 131.
opb: Predictive value of the positive test

question: Diagnostic power of the test is reflected by
exp: The performance of a screening test is measured by its predictive value which reflects the diagnostic power of the test. The predictive accuracy depends upon sensitivity, specificity and disease prevalence. Park 23e pg: 140

question: Population is 10, 000. Of these 20% is having disease. The screening test has 95% sensitivity and 80% specificity. PPV is-
exp: Ref: Parks 23rd edition pg 139 Construct a 2x2 table using the above data. 1900 1600 100 6400 PPV = TP / (TP +FP) = 1900/ (1900+1600) =54. 3

question: A study is planned to check stool occult blood positivity using hemoccult test among a group of paicipants aged 50 - 75 years. The test is repeated if result is positive. No repeating if the test is negative. What is the effect on sensitivity and specificity?
exp: SCREENING TESTS IN One test (after +ve result) after other Both tests applied together COMBINED SERIES PARALLEL SENSITIVITY Decreases Increases SPECIFICITY Increases Decreases PPV Increases Decreases NPV Decreases Increases

question: The purpose of screening test-

four main uses of screening inc ludes case detection, control of disease, reserch purposes, educational oppounities. screening also helps in the soing out of people who are at a higher risk.

question: Which of the following is not considered for selecting a screening test?
exp: Explanation: Criteria for screening. The test must satisfy the criteria of acceptability; repeatability and validity. Simplicity; safety, rapidity; ease of administration and cost are other considerations. Acceptability: Test should be acceptable to the people or whom it is aimed. In general, tests that are painful. discomforting or embarrassing (e. g.. rectal or vaginal examinations) are not likely to be acceptable to the population in mass campaigns. Repeatability: The test must give consistent results when repeated more than once on the same individual or material, under the same conditions. Validity (accuracy): The term validity refers to what extent the test accurately measures which it purports to measure. In other words, validity expresses the ability of a test to separate or distinguish those w! ho have the disease from those who do not. It has two components: Sensitivity and specificity. Sensitivity: It has been defined as the ability of a test to identify correctly all those who have the disease that is "true positive". Specificity: It is defined as the ability of a test to identify correctly those who do not have the disease, that is, "true negatives". The disease to be screened should fulfill following criteria: Prevalence should be high. There should he latent period / asymptomatic period. Natural history should be adequately known. Facility should be available for confirmation. Effective treatment

question: amount of previously unrecognised disease which is diagnosed by screening effor, is-
exp:
.

yield is the amount of previously unrecognised diseases that is diagnosed as a result of the screening effo. it depends upon many factors. like sensitivity and specificity of the tets in the detection programmes. for example by limiting a diabetes screening programme to persons over 40 years we can increase the yield of the screening test. high risk populations are usually selected for screening thus increasing the yield.

ref: park&; s textbook of preventive and social medicine, 22 nd edition, pg no132

question: The ability of a screening test to detect "true positive" is known as -
exp: Sensitivity is the ability of a test to identify correctly all those who have the disease, that is &; true positive&; Specificity is the ability of a test to identify correctly all those who do not have the disease, that is &; true negative&;

question: If Hemoccult test is negative for screening of colonic cancer, no fuher test is done. If the hemoccult test is positive the individual will have a second stool sample tested with Hemoccult II test. If this second sample is positive for blood, the individual will be referred for more extensive evaluation. The effect of net sensitivity and net specificity of this method of screening is
exp: SCREENING TEST USED IN SERIES: A population is subjected to one screening test followed by a second screening test is applied on those individuals only who test positive on th e1st screening test. Combined sensitivity of 2 tests A and B in series: Sensitivity (A) * Sensitivity (B) Combined specificity of 2 tests A and B in series: Specificity (A) + Specificiity (B) - SCREENING TEST USED IN PARALLEL: A population is subjected to two or more screening tests at the both (or all) screening tests. Combined sensitivity of 2 tests A and B in parallel: Sensitivity(A) + Sensitivity (B) - Combines specificity of 2 tests A and B in parallel: Specificity(A)*Specificity(B) Test in series Tests in parallel Combined sensitivity Decreases Increases Combined specificity Increases Decreases Combined PPV Increases Decreases Combined NPV Decreases Increases Ref: Simple Biostatistics by Indrayan and Indrayan 1st edition Pgno: 56
opa: Net sensitivity and net specificity are both increased
opb: Net sensitivity is decreased and net specificity is increased
opc: Net sensitivity is increased and net specificity is decreased
opd: Net sensitivity remains the same and net specificity is increased

question: Screening for condition recommended when-
exp: Ref: Parks 23rd edition pg 136. Screening is carried out in the hope that earlier diagnosis and subsequent treatment, orably alters the natural history of the disease in a significant propoion of those who are identified as "positive". Note: We don&; t do screening when the disease has a low case fatality ratio. Diagnostic tools/tests must be made available before doing a screening test. Otherwise it will be in vain. Effective treatment should be available prior to doing a screening test. Also Refer p. 135. Table 1.
opd: Early diagnosis can change disease course because of effective treatment

question: Screening for which carcinoma is beneficial -
exp: Ref: Parks 23rd edition pg 387 Prolonged early phase of the cancer in situ can be detected by the Pap smear. The present strategy is to screen women using visual inspection after application of freshly prepared 5% acetic acid solution.

question: The critieria for validity of a screening test are-
exp: Ref: Parks 23rd edition pg 138 Validity has 2 components: sensitivity and specificity. Validity (Accuracy) The term validity refers to what extend the test accurately measures what it purpos to measure. Accuracy refers to the closeness with which measured values agree with "true" values.

question: Too much false positives in a test is due to which of the following-
exp: Ref: Parks 25th edition pg 152 Tests with high sensitivity gives too much false positives. Note Specificity and sensitivity are inversely related. High sensitivity means low specificity. Specificity = TN/ (TN+ FP).. low specificity means low TN, meaning high FP

question: If a biochemical test gives the same reading for a sample on repeated testing. It is inferred that the measurement is-
exp: Ref: Parks 23rd edition pg 138 Precision means that the test must give consistent results when repeated more than once on the same individual or material under the same conditions. A screening test must satisfy the criteria of acceptability, repeatability, and validity, besides others such as yield, simplicity, safety, rapidity, ease of administration and cost.

question: A test was considered for diagnosing a disease. Out of 80 positive cases with this test, 40 actually had no disease. Out of 9920 tested negative cases 9840 actually had no disease. Calculate the sensitivity of the test-
exp: Ref: Parks 23rd edition pg 139 Sensitivity = TP / (TP + FP) = 40 / (40+80)=. 33

exp: . predictive value of a positive test is calculated as true positive divided by the sum of true positive and false positive expressed in percentage ref: park&; s textbook, 22 nd edition, pg no 130

question: Lead time is:
exp: Ans. (c) Time between detection of disease through screening and its clinical symptoms. Ref: K. Park 23rd ed. / 99-100* Lead time is the length of time between the detection of a disease and its usual clinical presentation and diagnosis. OR* It is the time between early diagnosis with screening, and when diagnosis would have been made without screening.
opa: Time from early diagnosis to starting treatment
opc: Time between detection of disease through screening and its clinical symptoms
opd: Time between clinical symptom to complete treatment

Reliability of a test depends on 3 major factors: Observer variation (intra and inter) Biological variation Errors relating to technical methods.

question: Screening for a disease is application in-
exp: . screening is defined as "the search for unre4cognized disease or defect by means of rapidly applied tests, examinations, or other procedures in apparently healthy individuals. detection programmes should be restricted to thoseconditions in which there is considerable time lag between disease onset and the usual time of diagnosis. in this period there are usually a number of critical points which determine both the severity of the disease and the success of any treatment in reversing the disease process. ref: park&; s textbook of preventive and social medicine, 22 nd edition, pg no127

question: More false positive cases in a community signify that the disease has

question: When a diagnostic test is used in series mode then-
exp: Ref: Parks 23rd edition pg 137 When used in series: Sensitivity decreases Specificity increases PPV increases NPV decreases When used in parallel: Sensitivity increases Specificity decreases PPV decreases NPV increases
opa: Sensitivity increases but the specificity decreases
opb: Specificity increases bu the sensitivity decreases

question: Multiphasis screening means -

incidence rate is defin ed as the number of new case occurring in a defined population during a specified period of time. it will be seen from the above definition that incidence rate refers only to new cases, and during a given period usually assumed as one year. it also refers in a specified population or "; population at risk"unless other denominators are chosen.

question: Positive predictive value is most affected by-

question: Screening of immigrants from infectious diseases such as Tuberculosis and Syphilis to protect the home population is an example of:
exp: Control of disease is also known as "Prospective screening". People are examined for the benefit of others:- Examples- Screening of Immigrants from infectious diseases such as Tuberculosis and Syphilis to protect the home population. Screening for streptococcal infection to prevent rheumatic fever. Prescriptive screening is defined as the presumptive identification of unrecognized disease, which does not arise from a patient's request:- Examples- Neonatal screening. Specific diseases sought by this method have included - Bacteriuria in pregnancy Breast cancer Cervical cancer Deafness in children Diabetes mellitus Iron deficiency anemia PKU Pulmonary tuberculosis Haemolytic disease of the newborn etc.

question: ELISA is performed on a population with low prevalence, What would be the result of performing double screening ELISA tests-
exp: Ref: Parks 23rd edition pg 139 Double ELISA meaning screening test is done in series. Series screening test: Sensitivity decreases Specificity increases PPV increases NPV decreases
opa: Increased sensitivity and positive predictive value
opb: Increased sensitivity and negative predictive value
opc: Increased specificity and positive predictive value
opd: Increased specificity and negative predictive value

Diagnostic power or Predictablity: includes positive and negative predictive values. in order to include or exclude the person.

question: Calculate positive predictive value of ELISA test for HIV with sensitivity 99%, specificity 99%. Prevalence of HIV in population is 5/1000.
exp: Ref: Parks 23rd edition pg139 Construct a 2x2 table using the above data. 4. 95 9. 95 0. 05 985. 05 PPV = TP / (TP + FP) = 4. 95/(4. 95+9. 95)=0. 34

exp: Ref: Parks 23rd edition pg 138 An ideal screening test should have 100 % sensitivity.

question: Evaluation of screening test is by-

question: Screening is a type of -
exp:
.

secondary prevention can be defined as"action which halts the progress of a disesease at its incipient stage and prevents complications. the specific interventions are early diagnosis including SCREENING tests, case finding programmes and adequate treatment, secondary prevention attempts to arrest the disease process; restore health by seeking out unrecognised disease and treating it before irreversible pathological changes have taken place; and to reverse communicability of infectious disesases. it may also protect others in the community from acquiring the infection and thus provide at once secondary prevention for the infected individuals and primary prevention for their potential contacts.

ref: park&; s textbook of preventive and social medicine, 22 nd edition, pg no39

question: Validity of an indicator means
exp: Ref: Parks 23rd edition pg 138 validity refers to what extend the test accurately measures what it purpos to measure. Validity includes - sensitivity and specificity.
opa: It should actually measure what it is supposed to measure
opb: The answer should be same if measured by different persons in similar circumstances
opc: Indicators should reflect changes in the situation concerned
opd: Indicators should have ability to obtain data needed

question: Primary and secondary case are used to define-
exp: . in actual practice we seldom know precisely the incubation period of a disese. but we know when an outbreak of disease occurs, say in a family of which is the smallest grouop and primary case is followed by 2 or 3 secondary cases within a sho time. the gap in time between the onset of the primary case and the secondary case is called the "serial interval" ref: park&; s textbook of preventive and social medicine, 22 nd edition, pg no96

question: You have diagnosed a patient clinically as having SLE and ordered 6 tests. Out of which 4 tests have come positive and 2 are negative. To determine the probability of SLE at negative. To determine the probability of SLE at this point, you need to know-
exp: . sensitivity is the ability of a test to identify correctly those who actually have the disease, that is true positives. specificity is the ability of a test to identify correctly those who in actual do not have the disease. prior probability of disease such as SLE can be calculated by knowing these. ref: park&; s textbook, 22 nd ed, pg 131
opa: Prior Probability of SLE; sensibility and specificity of each test
opb: Incidence of SLE predictive value of each test
opd: Relative risk of SLE in this patient

question: The active search for unrecognized disease or defect in apparently health people using rapidly applied tests or procedures is-
exp: Ref: Parks 23rd edition pg 135 Also Refer table 1; difference between screening and diagnostic tests.

question: Screening of cervical cancer at PHC level is done by?
exp: Ref: Parks 23rd edition pg 387 The prolonged early phase of cancer in situ can be detected by the Pap smear. The present strategy is to screen women using visual inspection after application of freshly prepared 5%acetic acid solution.

question: In which of the following disease, the overall survival is increased by screening procedure -
exp: . there is strong positive correlation between cancer colon and dietary fat. the studies have shown that increase in the dietary intake of fat has recently increased the incidence of ca colon in the western communities like japan. also dietary fibre intake is said to have a protective role in the development of carcinoma colon. the overall survival is increased by screening procedure - in the case of carcinoma colon. ref: park&; s textbook, 22 nd ed, pg 600

question: A test has a high false positive rate in a community. True is
exp: The propoion of false-positive results among those who test positive is 1 minus the positive predictive value. False positive (discovery) rate = 1- positive predictive value. As the disease prevalence increases, the positive predictive value increases. (PPV). As prevalence increase, PPV increase, False positive rate decrease.

question: Screening procedure is best for Ca of -
exp: . screening is best suited in the case of ceain disease. one among the following is carcinoma colon, the disease can be screened if it satisfies the following conditions such as, *an impoant health problem it must be *there should be a recognisable latent or early asymptomatic stage. *natural history of condition *tets that detect the disease prior to the onset of symptoms *an effective treatment. ref: park&; s textbook, 22 nd edition, pg no 131

question: Specificity of a screening test is the ability of a test to detect
exp: Specificity is defined as the ability of a test to identify correctly those who do not have the disease, that is &; true-negatives&; Sensitivity is defined as the ability of a test to identify correctly all those who have the disease, that is &; true-positive&;

question: For a screening test, 90% specificity means that 90% of non diseased persons will give a -
exp: a 90% specificity means that 90%of the non diseased persons will give "true negative result", 10% of non diseased people screened by the test will be wrongly classified as &;; diseased" when they are not. ref: park&; s textbook of preventive and social medicine, 22nd edition, pg no 131

question: Sensitivity is
exp: Repeated question
opa: True positive\/ true positive + false negative
opb: True negative\/ false positive + true negative
opc: True negative\/ true negative + false positive
opd: True negative\/ false negative + true positive

question: Which is most economical and best screening
exp: Ref: Parks 23rd edition pg 137 High-risk or selective screening: Screening will be most productive if applied selectively to high-risk groups, the groups defined on the basis of epidemiological research. Types of screening: Mass screening. High-risk or selective screening. Multi-phasic screening.

question: Example of multiphasic screening is
exp: Multiphasic screening: It is the application of two or more screening tests to a large population at one time instead of carrying out separate screening tests for single diseases. Randomised control studies suggested that multiphasic screening has not shown any benefit accruing to the population in terms of moality and morbidity reduction.
opa: Chest X-ray for TB on large population

question: True statement about PPV is:
exp: Ans. (a) It increases with prevalence. Ref: K. Park 23rd ed. /140-141# POSITIVE PREDICTIVE VALUE* Ability of screening test to identify correctly all those who have disease out of all those who test positive on a screening test.* It depends upon sensitivity, specificity and prevalence of a disease in a population* PPV of a screening is directly proportional to prevalence of disease* If Prevalence of a disease increases in a population, PPV increase for the screening test. PPV=TP/TP+FP x 100
